Award.AwardTitle: An Innovative Hybrid Program For Diversifying And Building Capacity In The STEM/ICT Workforce: ISTEM

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
This strategies project develops a program combining in-school mentoring with out of school informal education experiences involving the use of three types of mentors; college students, STEM professionals, and volunteers from the participant group community. The project targets Native American and Hispanic students in grades 3 - 8. The project recruits, trains and retains a minimum of 60 mentors during the 3 year project. Mentors from the three groups including members of the Pascua Yaqui Native American community and tribal members are paired with like numbers of mentees. The groups meet twice a month and engage in a minimum of 5 out of school informal science experiences during each year of the program. Program activities are guided by a culturally relevant theoretical framework, Funds of Knowledge, to determine the effectiveness of the combined effect of mentors from the three groups and the hybrid in-school and after school program. Funds of Knowledge provide mentors with theory and methods on how to identify, document, and build on the "hidden resources" found in the life-world of students to help them contextualize problems for ease of learning.

Program activities are be based on four of fourteen grand challenges in engineering from the National Academy of Engineering Grand Challenges for Scholars; 1) Energy and Environment, 2) Health, 3) Security and 4) Learning and Computation. The program intends to determine the comparative effects of the three mentoring groups. They will attempt to determine which group of mentors, if any, are more effective in engaging mentees in STEM fields. The use of the "learning-together" model as a metaphor for family and community involvement through volunteer mentors from the target community is tested as a new approach to increasing effectiveness of the mentor model. The project also tests whether the model will increase the likelihood that minority engineering undergraduates who serve as mentors will persist and graduate.

The project develops and provides structured technology intensive activities for mentors to use during their time with mentees at school that align with the informal out-of-school learning experiences. In addition, the program is aligned with each of the two participating schools science curriculum to assure continuity and mutual support of the activities.

POR.DRECONTENT:
iSTEM Outcomes Report

Broader Impact

Mentees across the five years were represented by mostly female (77%) and Native American (68%) and Hispanic (24%) students. During the first three years of the iSTEM program, 78 mentees participated with three types of mentors (tribal members, university students, and STEM professionals). During the fourth year, the addition of the STEM guides, 43 students participated, with 19 new students and 24 students continuing their 2nd (5),3rd (14), or 4th (5) year with the iSTEM program. The fifth and final year limited new student enrollment to six new students given project wind-down. Returning students included 13 students in their 2nd year, five students in their 3rd year, 14 students in their 4th year of participation, and one student that completed all five years beginning as a 3rd grader. In total, the iSTEM program actively engaged 108 students.

Funds of Knowledge

Curriculum modules were built upon the Funds of Knowledge (FoK) framework to create meaningful modules relevant to Native Americans and life in the desert southwest. FoK takes into account how families and communities develop and share knowledge along with the skills and talents related to that knowledge. All iSTEM modules were informed by FoK and relevant materials incorporated. For example, the Solar Energy module included adobe homes and Native clothing. The Water and Soil module included the history of Native American irrigation systems and Native plants and food. Additionally, the modules and related field trips highlighted STEM carreers local to the area.

Hybrid Program Design

Evaluation findings from the five years found that the lunch-time learning period with culminating field trips increased student knowledge and interest in STEM content. In addition, when asked about a future interest in science career on the post-test belief survey, 47% strongly agreed or agreed, with an additional 24% indicating maybe. Most mentees of STEM professionals (75%) reported interest in a STEM career followed by mentees of STEM guides (59%), University students (53%), and Tribal member mentors (35%). Of the students not paired with a mentor, 39% expressed interest in a STEM career. As a result of the iSTEM project, the data suggests that all four types of mentors successfully engaged students in activities during the lunchtime informal STEM program.

STEM Activities by Mentor Type

The results of mentors engaging their mentee resulted in four general findings: First, NA tribal and community mentors as well as UA students were able to facilitate the hand-on STEM activities and engage with their mentee effectively despite most lacking a STEM background. Second, for NA tribal mentors that had a prior and well-established trusting relationship with their mentee, they were able to begiin participating in STEM activities without having to initially develop a trusting relationship. Third, UA undergraduate and graduate students excelled in implementing the activities, but some lacked the ability to engage or facilitate a strong, trusting bond with the mentee despite mentor training prior to the matching process. Fourth, with regard to content, STEM professionals successfully interacted with student mentees, as their educational background enhanced the STEM content, and perhaps because all of the STEM professional mentors were older adults (compared to university student mentors), the ability to build a relationship with the student came more naturally to them. Each type of mentor brough strenghts to the relationship, and as a whole, all were successful in promoting STEM activities and career fields for 3rd -8th grade mentees.

Sustainability

Several features of the project will be sustained such as all curriculum materials were left for the schools and uploaded to the website; the developed relationship between the schools and the university can be maintained via filed trips, guest speakers, and voluntay mentoring; and the Family STEM Guide and Project Manual. Manuscripts and presentations will continue to be produced from the project, and will serve as the basis of future proposals to continue increased awareness and recruitment of underrepresented minorities and female students into STEM and ICT career fields.

Conclusion

The iSTEM project successfully engaged over 100 students exposing them to STEM activities, career fields, and exposure to the college campus and engagement with college students as mentors or STEM Guides. In addition, the mentoring program in Years1-4 provided an adult relationship to encourage and interest students in STEM. As part of the grant, four mentor types successfully facilitated and participated with students in STEM activities even when lacking a STEM background (Tribal mentors and some university students in non-STEM fields). Students thoroughly enjoyed the field trips, and spoke about those that were most meaningful such as the Star Party, Reid Park Zoo, Mt. Lemmon, and the Flandrau Planetarium. Involving the parents in the field trips also proved beneficial for gaining support of the student to pursue a STEM career and to have their parents support doing so.
